This has cost the Tak village much and in multiple ways.Death of a dreamSome of the deported youths have chosen to flee the village altogether, burdened with debt and creditors’ pressure. At least five such families have already left, said a resident. The family of Ram Budha was one of them. On April 28, 2015, Ram, who had returned to Nepal after working in Malaysia for eight years, took the illegal route to the US. He travelled through arduous trails for months and finally arrived in the country. Upon reaching the country, he was detained and had to stay at the detention camp for 27 months. When his refugee application was rejected, he was deported to Nepal in mid-December 2019. He lost Rs4.5 million in the process. He now owes over Rs6 million to creditors. “After the creditors began to put pressure on me, I couldn’t live in the village peacefully,” said Ram, who currently runs a vegetable farm in Tarakeshwar, Kathmandu.While those who got to the US through illegal routes and fortunately got refugee status there narrate their stories with pride, those who have been deported or returned from half-way have tragic tales to tell.Nanda Kala Gharti, who lives in a small stone house on the upper flank of Tak village, spends her days in melancholy. Her husband, Dhanlal, had chosen to take the illegal route to the US, and Nanda Kala, a mother of four, is living with the repercussions of his decision. Dhanlal had got into the US after a six-month long arduous journey and was detained immediately. He had to spend four years in the detention camp, before he was deported to Nepal. He had already lost Rs6 million.Nanda Kala said they now have an insurmountable crisis in their hands. Pointing to her son, she exclaimed, “When will he grow up, go abroad and pay back the loans!”Dhanlal himself tried to go to Croatia once and spent 15 days in Kathmandu for the process. But after he was turned down, he returned home dejected. “Now we will submit the passport to another agent [for Dhanlal’s trip abroad],” Nanda Kala said. “There’s no point staying here.”Stories that echo each otherThe situation in Sisne Rural Municipality is similar to that of Putha Uttarganga. Here, one can hear plenty of stories of those who have tried to go to the US and those who are fighting refugee cases there. Krishna Regmi, chair of the rural municipality, personally knows seven people who have been deported from the US.Gangaram Khadka, a resident of Sisne-3, runs a bee and chicken farm. Like other young men in his village, Khadka had headed off to the US via an illegal route on 27 March, 2018. He had reached the US via the New Delhi-Moscow-Barcelona-Bogota-Panama-Costa Rica-Nicaragua-Honduras-Guatemala-Mexico route. When he finally arrived in the US, he was detained and had to spend 11 months in detention. He was deported on 15 March, 2019. He had handed over Rs3.2 millions to the agent and spent Rs2 million to fight the case to become a refugee. “It’s not possible for me to pay back the loan while working in Nepal,” he said. “I aim to pay back some interest and head off abroad again.”For six months after Khadka was deported, he had anxiety and headache, he said, adding the three people from his village who were deported like him are also struggling with their mental health.Tikaram Pun, a 40-year-old resident of Bohora village in Musikot-4, is also haunted by his past journey. In September 2017, he reached the US after crossing 17 countries with the help of organised human traffickers. Of the 41 people in his group, 31 were from Rukum East and Rukum West, he said. Pun, who was detained on arrival in the US, spent 24 months in a detention camp. His refugee application was also refused and so he was deported along with eight other Nepalis. “When I returned, I started having mental health problems. I still suffer from them,” he said. Pun is under pressure from creditors and relatives to pay back the Rs9.2 million loan he had taken for the task.Those who died on the wayA group of 10 Bangladeshis and seven Nepalis, including Rupak Bohora of Bafikot-3 in Rukum West, were on a mission to reach Costa Rica through Colombia, Caribbean Coast, Capuragana and Panama. But while they were crossing a sea, their boat capsized. As many as 12 died in the incident, including six Nepalis. Rupak’s wife, Geeta, learned about the incident only after six days, on 25 June, 2021.“I still don’t know what exactly happened,” said Geeta, who had been married off at age 19 and is now a mother of two daughters. The only thing she knows is that Rupak has died and she is now all alone. And that she has Rs5 million in loan taken for Rupak’s trip. She showed a picture of her husband on her phone to this scribe and said, “I only have memories.”Lack of political will and legal remediesThe concrete bridge over Chewang river is on the edge of Tak village. On the walls of the bridge are paintings of political theorists like Marx, Engels, Lenin, Stalin and Mao, and the iconic slogan, ‘Workers of the world, unite!’, below them. But the slogan appears to be at odds with life in the village. Given the phenomenon of illegal travels to the US through the help of organised human traffickers, the whole village appears to be emptying. Neither the local governments are concerned about the phenomenon nor are the political parties paying attention.Puniraj Gharti, chair of Putha Uttarganga Rural Municipality, said though the trend is worrying, there’s nothing he can do. “How could we stop them from making the trip when they are struggling to make a living in the village?” he said.Krishna Regmi, chair of Sisne Rural Municipality, said that the vicious cycle of poverty started after marijuana farming was banned in the country. Then the Maoist insurgency added to the woe, forcing youths to migrate. The signing of the peace agreement in 2006 didn’t herald any change in the economy either and youths are struggling to get jobs. Organised human traffickers are cashing in on this sorry state of affairs, Regmi said. “Meter byajis [usurious lenders] are also promoting this phenomenon,” he added.The phenomenon is equally rife in Dang’s Tulsipur and Ghorahi. Ramesh Kumar Pandey, chair of Ghorai-15, says that even though many heading to the US are swindled, no complaints are filed at the ward office. “Only those who attempt to go to Saudi Arabia or Qatar file the complaints,” he said.One can infer from Pandey’s statements that the families of such illegal travellers don’t want to publicise the ordeals of their family members. On the one hand, agents threaten them to not publicise the issue; on the other, they fear they themselves would be punished by law.According to the Anti-Human Trafficking Bureau, as many as 178 Nepalis, including 174 men, have been deported from the US in the five fiscal years after 2018-19. Of them, the highest 49 are from Rukum while 37 are from Dang. The data doesn’t include those who returned after making it to the half-way or those who have been fighting the legal battle in the US for refugee status. But this data is enough to show that many such youths are from the ‘base areas’ of the Maoist insurgency.SSP Jeevan Shrestha, chief of the bureau, said that data on the number of such victims and the amounts they have spent is hard to collect since complaints are rarely filed with the police. “This is human trafficking but for a lack of law, we are still compelled to launch the cases as per Human Trafficking and Transportation (Control) Act 2074 BS,” Shrestha said. “The Act provides a maximum penalty of Rs250,000 for the offenders and 50 percent of that as compensation to the victims.” Without specific law, police also invoke the theft and organised crime act to punish the offenders, he added.On the one hand, police receive no complaints; on the other, the phenomenon sees no control.Bhaskar Gautam, a political scientist, says the rise in cases of human trafficking in the insurgency’s ‘base areas’ is due to the political system’s abject failure.While the Maoists raised issues related to livelihood, nationalism and a new kind of democracy to fuel their war machine, after the peace process, it is livelihoods that have been hit the hardest, Gautam said. “The traditional way of life and economy took a hit during the insurgency,” he said. “Developments after the peace process also failed to address that. What sprang up was organised human trafficking.”(Mahesh KC in Rukum East and Durgalal KC in Dang contributed to this report.)This report is prepared in collaboration with the Center for Investigative Journalism-Nepal.

title: Poor patients face difficulties accessing private hospital beds, limiting their access to quality healthcare.
content:
**Private Hospitals in Nepal Not Providing Required Free Services**

Despite government regulations, many private hospitals in Nepal are not providing free treatment to those in need. Hospitals are supposed to allocate 10% of their beds and provide free services to underprivileged patients, but this is often not happening.

Patients like Gyanumaya BK have incurred high medical expenses due to this issue. Hospitals often ignore government rules and do not willingly offer free services.

Monitoring bodies are not doing enough to ensure compliance, and some hospitals even provide fake documents to avoid inspections.

As a result, many needy patients are being deprived of essential healthcare services.
summary: Private hospitals in Pokhara, Chitwan, Biratnagar, Butwal disregard the government's Health Facility Operation Standards-2020, denying free or discounted medical services to the underprivileged.

title:
**AI in Education**

AI is changing education:

* **Personalized learning:** AI can tailor lessons to each student's needs.
* **Virtual assistants:** AI-powered assistants can help students with homework and research.
* **Automated grading:** AI can quickly and accurately grade assignments.
* **Improved teacher training:** AI can analyze teaching practices and provide feedback.
* **Creating accessible education:** AI can translate lessons and provide accommodations for students with disabilities.
content:
**AI in Education**

* AI is becoming common in the world we live in.
* Schools worry that students may use AI tools like ChatGPT to copy and paste answers without thinking about whether they're right or where they came from.
* AI detection systems are being made, but they're still new and not reliable.
* Instead of fighting against AI, schools should teach students skills they need to work with AI in the future.
* AI should be used wisely in teaching, learning, and testing in higher education.

**Concerns and Challenges**

* Some teachers worry that AI tools like ChatGPT make it easier for students to cheat and don't help them learn as much.
* Others are concerned that students are becoming less able to learn on their own and rely too much on AI for answers.
* Some students may feel less confident in their abilities because they think AI-generated content is better than their own work.
* It can be difficult to figure out which parts of AI-generated content students know and can use, and which parts they don't understand.

**Best Practices**

* Schools can use a scale to show how much AI is allowed in assessments, from "No AI" to "Full AI."
* Teachers can create questions that test critical thinking skills and require students to use their own knowledge instead of relying on AI.
* Teachers can reduce the likelihood of cheating by using in-person, in-time, and in-place assessments that don't involve technology.
summary: Learners will navigate a future saturated with AI, posing concerns for educators about the potential misuse of AI tools, such as ChatGPT, for assignments without proper evaluation, prompting a focus on integrating AI into education to equip students with AI-related skills that will be essential for their future careers.

title:
**Landslide Definition and Causes**

**What is a Landslide?**

* Movement of large amounts of rock, soil, or debris down slopes.

**Causes:**

* Heavy rainfall or snowmelt
* Steep slopes
* Unstable soil or rock
* Earthquakes or volcanic eruptions

**Types of Landslides**

* **Debris Flows:** Rapidly moving mixtures of soil, rock, and water.
* **Earth Flows:** Slow-moving landslides where soil behaves like a flowing liquid.
* **Rock Slides:** Large pieces of rock breaking off and sliding downslope.
* **Avalanches:** Landslides of snow, ice, or debris.

**Consequences of Landslides**

* Loss of life and property
* Damage to infrastructure (e.g., roads, bridges)
* Erosion and sedimentation
* Disruption of ecosystems

**Risk Reduction**

* Avoid building on steep slopes.
* Maintain vegetation to stabilize slopes.
* Control surface water drainage.
* Install early warning systems.
* Evacuate areas when landslides are imminent.
content:
**Papua New Guinea Landslide**

Over 2,000 people are feared dead after a landslide buried a village.

**Causes of Landslides**

* Gravity
* Water (rainwater, earthquakes, volcanic eruptions)
* Human activities (cutting trees, mining)

**Preventing Landslides**

* Avoid building in high-risk areas
* Protect forests (especially in shallow slopes)
* Use drainage systems and retaining walls
* Educate people about landslide risks
summary: A massive landslide in Papua New Guinea, caused by possible deforestation and other factors, has killed over 2,000 people, highlighting the need for identifying high-risk areas and implementing measures such as reforestation and structural stabilization to prevent future tragedies.

title:
**Jobs in Indian Elections**

Indian elections are largely influenced by the issue of jobs. Many voters consider the government's ability to create jobs when casting their ballots.

* **Job creation promises:** Politicians often pledge to create new jobs and improve employment opportunities.
* **Economic growth:** Voters want policies that promote economic growth and create jobs.
* **Education and skills:** Parties address the need for a skilled workforce to meet the demands of the job market.
* **Job security:** Voters prioritize policies that ensure stable and well-paying jobs.
* **Unemployment:** High unemployment rates can influence voter sentiment and affect election outcomes.
content:
**Key Concerns in Indian Elections**

* People are worried about rising prices and not enough jobs.
* Many people think the government needs to do more to create jobs.

**Political Promises**

* Congress: Promises over 3 million new government jobs.
* BJP: Promises jobs and benefits, but focuses more on non-job issues and blaming minorities.

**Job Market Challenges**

* Most young people struggle to find high-paying jobs.
* Even technical graduates face unemployment due to poor training.
* Many are forced to work in low-skill or low-paid occupations.
* Government job openings attract many applicants, indicating a lack of available positions.

**Government's Efforts**

* "Make in India" program aimed to boost manufacturing jobs, but results have been mixed.
* IT sector has provided jobs but employment is slowing down.
* Artificial Intelligence may further reduce IT job opportunities.

**Future Challenge**

* The new government needs to address the issue of youth unemployment.
summary: Amidst ongoing national elections, economic distress and inflation are key concerns for Indian voters, and even government supporters acknowledge the need for improved job creation.

title: Not suitable for drinking.
content:
**Safe Drinking Water in Kathmandu**

Kathmandu residents have been facing unsafe drinking water issues for years, including algae and harmful particles in bottled water. Despite having water resources, the government has failed to provide clean water.

Due to budget issues, water testing is limited, increasing the risk of waterborne diseases like cholera and dysentery. Bottled water is widely used, but many sources remain unchecked due to poor monitoring.

Water pollution is caused by human activities, sewage, and climate change. The government should allocate more inspectors for water testing and develop monitoring plans for all seasons.

Water suppliers need to ensure safety and follow quality standards. Safe drinking water is a right, and the government and individuals have a role to play in protecting it.
summary: Kathmandu residents continue to face unsafe drinking water due to contamination, lack of testing, and government negligence, despite water resource abundance.

title: Support and fund organizations that work directly with local communities.
content:
**Infrastructure in Remote Nepal**

People in remote Nepal still lack basic services like water, transportation, and communication.

**Federal System**

The federal system was supposed to improve infrastructure in rural areas, but it has not yet met expectations.

**Basic Needs**

Roads, telephone, and internet are essential for villages to develop.

**Decentralization**

Services should be decentralized to wards, which were formerly independent villages.

**Mobile Services**

Local units can use mobile government teams to provide services directly to villages.

**Provincial Support**

Provincial governments need to play a stronger role in improving service delivery.

**Retaining Villages**

Improved infrastructure is crucial to keep people from leaving villages due to lack of opportunities.
summary: Despite the implementation of the federal system in Nepal, infrastructure development in remote areas remains neglected, resulting in struggles for basic facilities such as drinking water and social security allowances, highlighting the need for improved service delivery to prevent rural depopulation.

title: Relax and don't stress.
content:
**Summary:**

In Nepal, there's a lot of pressure for couples to have children. Childless couples are often viewed as odd and women are often blamed. This pressure can be stressful, even if infertility is not the reason for not having children. Despite declining fertility rates, women continue to face societal expectations to have children. This pressure can harm women's well-being and limit their choices. It's important for women to have the right to decide about their own bodies and families, without societal pressure.
summary: In Nepal, societal pressure forces childless couples to have babies, blaming women for infertility despite declining fertility rates due to family planning and education, reflecting the patriarchal nature of Nepali society where women's agency over their bodies is undermined.

title: People are now supporting leaders who are democratically elected but have authoritarian tendencies.
content:
**Human Rights Situation Worldwide**

* Human rights are declining everywhere: suppression of free speech, press, assembly, women's rights, and minority rights.
* Armed conflicts are escalating, leading to increased deaths.

**South Asia**

* Nepal and Sri Lanka are experiencing shrinking civic space and restricted freedom of expression, especially online.
* Use of excessive force by police during protests is on the rise.
* Crimes from the past remain unpunished.

**Reasons for Backsliding**

* Economic inequality and populism
* Impacts of the COVID-19 pandemic
* Authoritarian leaders exploiting public frustrations with democracy

**Authoritarianism in Nepal**

* Displayed by local officials, such as the Kathmandu mayor's actions against vendors and the poor
* Arrest of media owner Sirohiya seen as an attempt to stifle dissent

**Regulating Artificial Intelligence (AI)**

* Unregulated AI poses risks like discrimination and privacy violations
* Facial recognition for mass surveillance should not be allowed
* European Union has taken some steps to regulate AI, but other countries need to follow suit

**Transitional Justice in Nepal**

* Process has stalled due to fear of peace being disrupted
* Categorization of crimes into "serious" and "non-serious" is problematic and could lead to impunity
* People are losing trust in the justice system

**International Obligations**

* Nepal may face international intervention if justice is delayed
* Cases within universal jurisdiction can be pursued against perpetrators outside Nepal

**Custodial Deaths and Impunity**

* Abuse of power by police and state authorities needs to be monitored and investigated
* Impunity is rampant

**Climate Change and Nepal**

* Nepal is highly vulnerable to climate change despite low emissions
* Industrialized countries have failed to fulfill their responsibilities
* Amnesty International advocates for climate justice and financial support for affected countries
summary: Human rights are rapidly backsliding globally, with the use of disproportionate force, shrinking civic spaces, and weaponized laws in Nepal's South Asian region.

title: If Oli continues his political tactics, other political parties may join together to form alliances against him.
content:
**Unified Socialist Party (CPN-US) Prepares for General Convention**

**History and Rationale for Split:**
* CPN-US formed in 2021 due to a split from the CPN-UML.
* Split caused by disagreements over policy and party direction.

**Goals for General Convention:**
* Formulate clear policies focused on prosperity and economic development.
* Establish a leadership that can implement these policies effectively.

**Leadership:**
* Discussion underway to determine new leadership.
* Former UML leaders advocate for implementing new policies.

**Challenges and Opportunities:**
* Party faces criticism for lack of clear policies and leadership.
* Struggle to retain members and expand base.
* Ongoing internal power struggles hinder party growth.

**Political Alliances:**
* CPN-US supports cooperation with Nepali Congress to safeguard democracy and the constitution.
* Party acknowledges differences within the coalition but remains committed.

**Relevance of CPN-US:**
* Party aims to address shortcomings of CPN-UML and Maoist Centre.
* Advocates for economic independence and social change.

**Mergers vs. Unification:**
* CPN-US believes in unification based on shared policies, not merely power-sharing.
* Mergers often fail when driven by personal interests.
summary: The CPN (Unified Socialist), founded in 2021 after a split from the CPN-UML, is holding its first general convention to address policy issues, leadership changes, and its relevance in Nepal's communist landscape.

title: Every effort must be made to give justice to victims of conflict.
content:
**Overview of Hanaa Singer-Hamdy's Interview**

**Background and Return to Nepal**

- Hanaa Singer-Hamdy is the UN Resident Coordinator in Nepal.
- She returned to Nepal after previously serving as UNICEF Chief in the country.

**Nepal's Development Progress and Challenges**

- Nepal has made significant progress over the past decade, including:
    - Poverty reduction
    - Declining child and maternal mortality
    - Improvements in nutrition and sanitation
- Nepal is scheduled to graduate from Least Developed Country (LDC) status by 2026.
- Main challenges include:
    - Reducing poverty and inequality
    - Addressing climate change and environmental degradation
    - Generating high economic growth

**Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs)**

- Nepal is on track to achieve many SDGs.
- Challenges remain, including data gaps and funding shortages.
- Partnerships are crucial for addressing these gaps.

**Investment and Finance for Development**

- The Nepal Investment Summit showcased Nepal's readiness for private investment.
- The UN supports Nepal in attracting investment, increasing trade competitiveness, and reducing trade deficits.
- Blended finance approaches can help mobilize private sector investment.

**UN Sustainable Development Cooperation Framework (UNSDCF)**

- The UNSDCF aligns with Nepal's national priorities.
- It focuses on sustainable economic transformation, inclusive human development, environmental sustainability, and effective governance.
- The UNSDCF promotes partnerships and leaves no one behind.

**Climate Change and Disaster Resilience**

- Nepal is vulnerable to climate change.
- The UN supports Nepal in promoting disaster preparedness, adaptation, and mitigation.
- Women and marginalized groups are prioritized in these efforts.

**Peace Process**

- The UN encourages Nepal to conclude its peace process, including transitional justice.
- The inclusion of victims and compliance with international obligations are crucial.

**Nepal's Role in Global Forums**

- Nepal has led discussions on climate change, LDC issues, and human rights.
- It serves as a bridge between major powers.

**Addressing Multilateralism and International Polarisation**

- The UN promotes dialogue and diplomacy to encourage cooperation among member states.
- The Summit of the Future aims to enhance cooperation and address global governance gaps.
summary: In a UN partnership with Nepal, United Nations Resident Coordinator Hanaa Singer-Hamdy highlights Nepal's progress in poverty reduction, maternal and child mortality decline, and human development, while acknowledging challenges in achieving LDCs and SDGs, seeking investment, and addressing conflict and human rights issues.

title:
Padam Giri, an expert in human optimization and longevity, shared his insights on:

- **Sleep:** Aim for 7-9 hours of quality sleep, avoiding late-night caffeine and alcohol.
- **Nutrition:** Focus on a whole-food, plant-based diet, with ample fruits, vegetables, and whole grains.
- **Movement:** Engage in regular exercise, including both indoor and outdoor activities.
- **Mindfulness:** Practice mindfulness meditation and deep breathing exercises to reduce stress and improve mental well-being.
- **Cognition:** Train your brain through activities like reading, puzzles, and learning new skills.
- **Social Connection:** Nurture relationships and engage in meaningful social interactions.
- **Lifelong Learning:** Continuously pursue knowledge and expand your horizons to keep your mind engaged.
content:
**Budget Session Begins with Ongoing Dispute**

- The budget session of Parliament starts Friday with no resolution to the dispute over investigating a deputy prime minister.
- The ruling CPN-UML party wants a broader investigation of cooperative fraud, while the opposition Nepali Congress insists on a specific committee targeting the deputy prime minister.

**Government Plans for Productivity**

- The Minister of Law, Justice, and Parliamentary Affairs, Padam Giri, plans to make the session more productive.
- He aims to have crucial bills approved, including those on transitional justice, education, and banking.

**Bill Drafting and Public Consultation**

- Giri acknowledges that bill drafting has not been fully consultative in the past.
- He commits to broader discussions in the future, including public input on bills related to public concerns.

**Transitional Justice Bill**

- The Transitional Justice Act amendment bill remains contentious, with debates over defining serious violations and sentencing.
- The government and opposition are working to find common ground.

**Recommendation Committee for Transitional Justice Commissions**

- A committee to recommend names for transitional justice commissions has been formed despite reservations.
- The committee will proceed despite the delay in the bill's endorsement.

**Supreme Court Vacancies**

- Three positions on the Supreme Court are vacant, with a fourth to open soon.
- Justice appointments are expected to be made in the coming weeks.

**Constitutional Amendment for Electoral System**

- There have been calls to amend the constitution to revisit the electoral system.
- The government has not discussed this possibility.

**Possibility of UML-Congress Alliance**

- There are no current discussions of a coalition between the CPN-UML and Nepali Congress.
summary: Nepal's budget session starts amidst stalled probe panel talks, with the government aiming to endorse crucial bills despite ongoing opposition resistance.

title: Fire incidents will make the next two months difficult.
content:
**Fire Incidents in Nepal**

**Issue:**
Nepal has experienced a significant increase in fire incidents in recent weeks, leading to loss of life and property damage.

**Causes:**
* Lack of rainfall this winter
* Soaring temperatures
* High winds
* Accumulation of forest litter
* Stubble burning

**Impacts:**
* Destruction of homes and settlements
* Loss of life
* Damage to ecosystems
* Air pollution

**Government Response:**
* Training community forest groups, local volunteers, and security agencies
* Providing portable fire pumps
* Using helicopters to fight fires
* Equipping local governments with disaster management resources
* Promoting awareness campaigns

**Other Factors:**
* Migration of youths away from rural areas
* Increased forest coverage, but lack of fire protection resources
* Deserted homesteads and empty settlements
* Insufficient risk assessment and disaster preparedness in large buildings
summary: Fire incidents have been escalating in Nepal due to increased temperatures, inadequate rainfall, and wind gusts, resulting in significant losses including human lives, homes, and settlements.

title: Muluki Ain is Nepal's legal code.
content: The Muluki Ain, a legal code made in 1854, was not just about supporting the caste system. It also established a common set of laws for the whole country and defined the roles of the government, which helped stop unfair decisions. While the code recognized the caste system, it also called for reforms to make sure punishments were the same for everyone, regardless of their caste. The code covered many aspects of life, including social customs and traditions.
summary: A comprehensive translation of Nepal's 1854 Muluki Ain highlights the legal code's role in rationalizing judicial structure, establishing rule of law, and addressing caste system inequities.

title:
Misinformation, or misleading news, is false or inaccurate information spread with the intent to deceive or misinform. It can be spread through various channels, such as social media, traditional media, or word-of-mouth. Misinformation can have negative consequences, including:

- Undermining trust in institutions
- Promoting discrimination
- Causing harm to individuals or groups
- Threatening public health

It is important to be aware of misinformation and to be critical of information you are presented with. Consider the source, check the facts, and be cautious of emotional appeals.
content:
**Sinohydro Clarification:**

Sinohydro denies claims in a news report that it failed to pay taxes for materials used in the Melamchi project. The company states that:

* All materials were legally sourced and purchased from local and foreign vendors.
* Aggregate used for concrete and backfill was purchased locally with taxes paid.
* Backfill stone and hard stone were recycled from excavated materials.
* Sinohydro has paid all vendors and suppliers, and has documentation to prove it.

The company claims the news report is misleading and should be corrected.
summary: Sinohydro disputes The Kathmandu Post's claim of unpaid taxes on resources used in the Melamchi Water Supply Project, stating it legally sourced materials and paid all vendors.

title: Misunderstanding occurs when someone interprets a message differently than intended by the sender due to factors such as poor communication, different perspectives, or cultural differences. It can lead to misinterpretations, conflicts, and misunderstandings.
content:
**Japan's Hiring of Nepali Workers**

**Misunderstandings:**

* **Government Involvement:** The agreement is not government-to-government (G2G). Nepali workers will sign contracts directly with Japanese employers.
* **Third-Party Agencies:** Private agencies are not banned from participating in the process of sending workers to Japan.

**Important Points:**

* Japan needs foreign workers due to a labor shortage.
* 207 Nepalis passed the care worker language test and 234 passed the technical test in October 2020. However, none have yet found jobs.
* Japanese companies may not cover airfare, insurance, or medical expenses for Nepali workers, as this depends on individual contracts.
* Japan has also signed agreements with Pakistan, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka to hire workers from those countries.
summary: Japan's labor market shortages led to a 2019 agreement with Nepal for specified skilled workers (SSW), though misunderstandings about government involvement, private agencies, and job placement costs may hinder its smooth implementation.

title: contributions-to-nepali
content: Professor Hutt thanks Deepak Thapa for bringing attention to the future of Nepali studies in Europe and America and acknowledges Krishna Pradhan's contributions to teaching Nepali at SOAS University of London. Professor Hutt expresses regret that future students in the UK will not have access to Nepali language and cultural courses due to the retirement of Professor Pradhan.
summary: Professor Michael Hutt expresses gratitude to Deepak Thapa for acknowledging his work and highlights the significant contributions of Krishna Pradhan in establishing Nepali studies at SOAS, which are now discontinued.

title: chhaupadi-persists
content: While feminine issues are addressed every now and then, not everything is taken seriously, and the unspoken issues go unnoticed. Here, I’m not only addressing the horrendous issue of Chhaupadi itself but also speaking of those women and girls who fall prey to this absurd menstrual practice.Ever thought what travelling back in time would feel like? Many in Nepal do not have to imagine, as such old and evil practises continue to occur in the 21st century!Chhaupadi is a flawed tradition connected to the taboo surrounding menstruation that prohibits Hindu menstruators from participating in normal family activities while on their period, as they are considered impure. Although it is said to be practised in the rural part of the country, it does exist in urban areas, too. Going back to its roots, we could perhaps rationalise that women were asked to stay cautious when menstruating because humans were closely surrounded by wildlife. The stench of blood during their period may have made them more vulnerable to attacks from these animals. But even this absurd line of thought doesn't make much sense anymore. The practise was made illegal in 2005, but cases related to it were reported as recent as 2019. News headlines vouched for fatalities on this account. But why are there such trivial punishments for such an offence? Shouldn’t the punishments be rethought to strongly discourage Chhaupadi altogether?Moreover, the reported cases are just the tip of the iceberg. The more you look into it, there are bound to be cases that have gone unreported because nothing immediately tragic occurred. This letter is a call for all of us to come together to fight this social plague. While the legal implications of such an offence are ambiguous, let's collectively decide that the societal implications of it will be grave. Let's refuse to accept such atrocities for our mothers, sisters and, above all, ourselves.Gauri Tandon, via email
summary: While feminine issues are addressed every now and then, not everything is taken seriously, and the unspoken issues go unnoticed. Here, I’m not only addressing the horrendous issue of Chhaupadi itself but also speaking of those women and girls who fall prey to this absurd menstrual practice.Ever thought what travelling back in time would feel like? Many in Nepal do not have to imagine, as such old and evil practises continue to occur in the 21st century!Chhaupadi is a flawed tradition connected to the taboo surrounding menstruation that prohibits Hindu menstruators from participating in normal family activities while on their period, as they are considered impure. Although it is said to be practised in the rural part of the country, it does exist in urban areas, too. Going back to its roots, we could perhaps rationalise that women were asked to stay cautious when menstruating because humans were closely surrounded by wildlife. The stench of blood during their period may have made them more vulnerable to attacks from these animals. But even this absurd line of thought doesn't make much sense anymore. The practise was made illegal in 2005, but cases related to it were reported as recent as 2019. News headlines vouched for fatalities on this account. But why are there such trivial punishments for such an offence? Shouldn’t the punishments be rethought to strongly discourage Chhaupadi altogether?Moreover, the reported cases are just the tip of the iceberg. The more you look into it, there are bound to be cases that have gone unreported because nothing immediately tragic occurred. This letter is a call for all of us to come together to fight this social plague. While the legal implications of such an offence are ambiguous, let's collectively decide that the societal implications of it will be grave. Let's refuse to accept such atrocities for our mothers, sisters and, above all, ourselves.Gauri Tandon, via email
